issue.title: Make FramePayload.Data class-backed

labels.name: patch-version-bump-only
labels.description: For PRs that when merged will only cause a bump of the patch version, ie. 1.0.x -> 1.0.(x+1)

issue.body:
Motivation:

Using indirect cases makes unwrapping and rewrapping HTTP/2 frames more expensive than it needs to be. As FramePayload.Data is essentially always stuffed into a FramePayload enum, we may as well just class-back it and avoid the extra allocs.

Modifications:

Make FramePayload.Data class-backed

Result:

Fewer allocations in many use-cases

### Motivation:

Moving the `HTTP1ProxyConnectHandler` into `swift-nio-extras` will make the
code which is generally useful when dealing with HTTP1 proxies available
more easily to a wider audience.

### Modifications:

The code and tests are copied over from https://github.com/swift-server/async-http-client/blob/0b5bec741bfcf941e208d937de2ec29affe750a7/Sources/AsyncHTTPClient/ConnectionPool/ChannelHandler/HTTP1ProxyConnectHandler.swift.

### Result:

`HTTP1ProxyConnectHandler` will be surfaced via the `NIOExtras` library

issue.title: cap read+pread POSIX read sizes at Int32.max
issue.body:
### Motivation:

According to `read`/`pread` man page, reads may return `EINVAL` if "The value provided for `nbyte` exceeds `INT_MAX`". In practice on Darwin it is observed that this happens for `>Int32.max`.

### Modifications:

For `read`/`pread` wrappers in `NIOPosix` we now set `nbyte` to `Int32.max` if it exceeds that value.

### Result:

We will no longer receive `EINVAL` signals and fail preconditions for reads larger than` Int32.max`. reads larger than `Int32.max` will return up to `Int32.max` bytes.

comment.body: Can one of the admins verify this patch?

issue.title: Content length verifier negative check
issue.body:
**NOTE:** This PR is in draft state because it includes unmerged code from a separate PR - https://github.com/apple/swift-nio-http2/pull/360

`ContentLengthVerifier` `init` throws on negative values

### Motivation:

We discovered that this code path can result in an arithmetic overflow in the case where the content-length header has `INT_MIN` value. Since negative content-lengths don't have any meaning anyway we may as well throw if we encounter one so the decoding can be aborted.

### Modifications:

`ContentLengthVerifier` init throws a `ContentLengthHeaderNegative` error when the decoded value is `< 0`

### Result:

We will no longer panic for `INT_MIN` content-lengths and will fail decoding if a negative value is encountered.

comment.body: Can one of the admins verify this patch?

issue.title: Content length verifier negative check
issue.body:
**NOTE:** This PR is in draft state because it includes unmerged code from a separate PR - https://github.com/apple/swift-nio-http2/pull/360

`ContentLengthVerifier` `init` throws on negative values

### Motivation:

We discovered that this code path can result in an arithmetic overflow in the case where the content-length header has `INT_MIN` value. Since negative content-lengths don't have any meaning anyway we may as well throw if we encounter one so the decoding can be aborted.

### Modifications:

`ContentLengthVerifier` init throws a `ContentLengthHeaderNegative` error when the decoded value is `< 0`

issue.title: Content length verifier negative check
issue.body:
**NOTE:** This PR is in draft state because it includes unmerged code from a separate PR - https://github.com/apple/swift-nio-http2/pull/360

`ContentLengthVerifier` `init` throws on negative values

### Motivation:

We discovered that this code path can result in an arithmetic overflow in the case where the content-length header has `INT_MIN` value. Since negative content-lengths don't have any meaning anyway we may as well throw if we encounter one so the decoding can be aborted.

### Modifications:

`ContentLengthVerifier` init throws a `ContentLengthHeaderNegative` error when the decoded value is `< 0`

### Result:

We will no longer panic for `INT_MIN` content-lengths and will fail decoding if a negative value is encountered.

issue.title: ContentLengthVerifier checks all header vals match
issue.body:
Motivation:

Per fetch (https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/#content-length-header), repeated values of Content-Length are fine if they’re the same, and an error otherwise.

Modifications:

Iterate over all supplied content-length headers and check for inconsistency.

Note that as per the linked spec, the check for matching values is done _before_ the string to integer conversion. This means for example we will throw for header values "1234" and "01234" complaining of a mismatch even though they are numerically equivalent.

Result:

ContentLengthVerifier will throw if inconsistent content-length values are found.

issue.title: Special case EventLoopPromise.succeed() when Value is Void
issue.body:
Motivation:

To succeed an `EventLoopPromise<Void>` users must pass a void-value to it, e.g.:
`promise.succeed(())`
`promise.succeed(Void())`
It would be nice if we could spell this as `promise.succeed()`.

For [issue](https://github.com/apple/swift-nio/issues/2310)

Modifications:

- add `func succeed()` for `Void` type via `extension`

Result: 

Users can use `succeed` without `Void` type declaration

issue.title: Make FramePayload.Data class-backed

labels.name: patch-version-bump-only
labels.description: For PRs that when merged will only cause a bump of the patch version, ie. 1.0.x -> 1.0.(x+1)

issue.body:
Motivation:

Using indirect cases makes unwrapping and rewrapping HTTP/2 frames more expensive than it needs to be. As FramePayload.Data is essentially always stuffed into a FramePayload enum, we may as well just class-back it and avoid the extra allocs.

Modifications:

Make FramePayload.Data class-backed

Result:

Fewer allocations in many use-cases

issue.title: Migrate http1 proxy connect handler
issue.body:
### Motivation:

Moving the `HTTP1ProxyConnectHandler` into `swift-nio-extras` will make the
code which is generally useful when dealing with HTTP1 proxies available
more easily to a wider audience.

### Modifications:

The code and tests are copied over from https://github.com/swift-server/async-http-client/blob/0b5bec741bfcf941e208d937de2ec29affe750a7/Sources/AsyncHTTPClient/ConnectionPool/ChannelHandler/HTTP1ProxyConnectHandler.swift.

### Result:

`HTTP1ProxyConnectHandler` will be surfaced via the `NIOExtras` library

issue.title: cap read+pread POSIX read sizes at Int32.max
issue.body:
### Motivation:

According to `read`/`pread` man page, reads may return `EINVAL` if "The value provided for `nbyte` exceeds `INT_MAX`". In practice on Darwin it is observed that this happens for `>Int32.max`.

### Modifications:

For `read`/`pread` wrappers in `NIOPosix` we now set `nbyte` to `Int32.max` if it exceeds that value.

### Result:

We will no longer receive `EINVAL` signals and fail preconditions for reads larger than` Int32.max`. reads larger than `Int32.max` will return up to `Int32.max` bytes.

comment.body: Can one of the admins verify this patch?

issue.title: Content length verifier negative check
issue.body:
**NOTE:** This PR is in draft state because it includes unmerged code from a separate PR - https://github.com/apple/swift-nio-http2/pull/360

`ContentLengthVerifier` `init` throws on negative values

### Motivation:

We discovered that this code path can result in an arithmetic overflow in the case where the content-length header has `INT_MIN` value. Since negative content-lengths don't have any meaning anyway we may as well throw if we encounter one so the decoding can be aborted.

### Modifications:

`ContentLengthVerifier` init throws a `ContentLengthHeaderNegative` error when the decoded value is `< 0`

### Result:

We will no longer panic for `INT_MIN` content-lengths and will fail decoding if a negative value is encountered.

comment.body: Can one of the admins verify this patch?

issue.title: ContentLengthVerifier checks all header vals match
issue.body:
Motivation:

Per fetch (https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/#content-length-header), repeated values of Content-Length are fine if they’re the same, and an error otherwise.

Modifications:

Iterate over all supplied content-length headers and check for inconsistency.

Note that as per the linked spec, the check for matching values is done _before_ the string to integer conversion. This means for example we will throw for header values "1234" and "01234" complaining of a mismatch even though they are numerically equivalent.

Result:

ContentLengthVerifier will throw if inconsistent content-length values are found.

comment.body: Can one of the admins verify this patch?

issue.title: ContentLengthVerifier checks all header vals match
issue.body:
Motivation:

Per fetch (https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/#content-length-header), repeated values of Content-Length are fine if they’re the same, and an error otherwise.

Modifications:

Iterate over all supplied content-length headers and check for inconsistency.

Note that as per the linked spec, the check for matching values is done _before_ the string to integer conversion. This means for example we will throw for header values "1234" and "01234" complaining of a mismatch even though they are numerically equivalent.

Result:

ContentLengthVerifier will throw if inconsistent content-length values are found.

comment.body: Can one of the admins verify this patch?

issue.title: Special case EventLoopPromise.succeed() when Value is Void
issue.body:
Motivation:

To succeed an `EventLoopPromise<Void>` users must pass a void-value to it, e.g.:
`promise.succeed(())`
`promise.succeed(Void())`
It would be nice if we could spell this as `promise.succeed()`.

For [issue](https://github.com/apple/swift-nio/issues/2310)

Modifications:

- add `func succeed()` for `Void` type via `extension`

Result: 

Users can use `succeed` without `Void` type declaration

issue.title: Make FramePayload.Data class-backed

labels.name: patch-version-bump-only
labels.description: For PRs that when merged will only cause a bump of the patch version, ie. 1.0.x -> 1.0.(x+1)

issue.body:
Motivation:

Using indirect cases makes unwrapping and rewrapping HTTP/2 frames more expensive than it needs to be. As FramePayload.Data is essentially always stuffed into a FramePayload enum, we may as well just class-back it and avoid the extra allocs.

Modifications:

Make FramePayload.Data class-backed

Result:

Fewer allocations in many use-cases

issue.title: Migrate http1 proxy connect handler
issue.body:
### Motivation:

Moving the `HTTP1ProxyConnectHandler` into `swift-nio-extras` will make the
code which is generally useful when dealing with HTTP1 proxies available
more easily to a wider audience.

### Modifications:

The code and tests are copied over from https://github.com/swift-server/async-http-client/blob/0b5bec741bfcf941e208d937de2ec29affe750a7/Sources/AsyncHTTPClient/ConnectionPool/ChannelHandler/HTTP1ProxyConnectHandler.swift.

### Result:

`HTTP1ProxyConnectHandler` will be surfaced via the `NIOExtras` library

issue.title: cap read+pread POSIX read sizes at Int32.max
issue.body:
### Motivation:

According to `read`/`pread` man page, reads may return `EINVAL` if "The value provided for `nbyte` exceeds `INT_MAX`". In practice on Darwin it is observed that this happens for `>Int32.max`.

### Modifications:

For `read`/`pread` wrappers in `NIOPosix` we now set `nbyte` to `Int32.max` if it exceeds that value.

### Result:

We will no longer receive `EINVAL` signals and fail preconditions for reads larger than` Int32.max`. reads larger than `Int32.max` will return up to `Int32.max` bytes.

comment.body: Can one of the admins verify this patch?

issue.title: Content length verifier negative check
issue.body:
**NOTE:** This PR is in draft state because it includes unmerged code from a separate PR - https://github.com/apple/swift-nio-http2/pull/360

`ContentLengthVerifier` `init` throws on negative values

### Motivation:

We discovered that this code path can result in an arithmetic overflow in the case where the content-length header has `INT_MIN` value. Since negative content-lengths don't have any meaning anyway we may as well throw if we encounter one so the decoding can be aborted.

### Modifications:

`ContentLengthVerifier` init throws a `ContentLengthHeaderNegative` error when the decoded value is `< 0`

### Result:

We will no longer panic for `INT_MIN` content-lengths and will fail decoding if a negative value is encountered.

comment.body: Can one of the admins verify this patch?

issue.title: ContentLengthVerifier checks all header vals match
issue.body:
Motivation:

Per fetch (https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/#content-length-header), repeated values of Content-Length are fine if they’re the same, and an error otherwise.

Modifications:

Iterate over all supplied content-length headers and check for inconsistency.

Note that as per the linked spec, the check for matching values is done _before_ the string to integer conversion. This means for example we will throw for header values "1234" and "01234" complaining of a mismatch even though they are numerically equivalent.

Result:

ContentLengthVerifier will throw if inconsistent content-length values are found.

comment.body: Can one of the admins verify this patch?

issue.title: Special case EventLoopPromise.succeed() when Value is Void
issue.body:
Motivation:

To succeed an `EventLoopPromise<Void>` users must pass a void-value to it, e.g.:
`promise.succeed(())`
`promise.succeed(Void())`
It would be nice if we could spell this as `promise.succeed()`.

For [issue](https://github.com/apple/swift-nio/issues/2310)

Modifications:

- add `func succeed()` for `Void` type via `extension`

Result: 

Users can use `succeed` without `Void` type declaration

comment.body: Can one of the admins verify this patch?

Result: 

Users can use `succeed` without `Void` type declaration

issue.title: Special case EventLoopPromise.succeed() when Value is Void
issue.body:
Motivation:

To succeed an `EventLoopPromise<Void>` users must pass a void-value to it, e.g.:
`promise.succeed(())`
`promise.succeed(Void())`
It would be nice if we could spell this as `promise.succeed()`.

For [issue](https://github.com/apple/swift-nio/issues/2310)

Modifications:

- add `func succeed()` for `Void` type via `extension`

Result: 

Users can use `succeed` without `Void` type declaration
